3.text:
3 (a) Any two odd primes added correctly → 1 mark  
    1 AO2.1a  
    Example: 3 + 5 = 8  

  (b) An odd integer squared with correct result → 1 mark  
    1 AO2.1a  
    Example: 5² = 25

10.text:
Question 10 (a)(i)  
• Answer: Positive correlation  
• Marks: 1  
• Guidance (1 AO1.1):  
  – Condone “positive” or correct description (e.g. “As the temperature increases, more ice creams are sold.”)

Question 10 (a)(ii)  
• Answer: Correct reason, e.g. “He sold far more ice creams than you would expect him to for a 20°C day.”  
• Marks: 1  
• Guidance (1 AO2.3a):  
  – Accept similar reasoning showing that sales exceed what would normally be predicted by temperature alone.

Question 10 (b)(i)  
• Answer: 75–95  
• Marks: 1  
• Guidance (1 AO1.3a)

Question 10 (b)(ii)  
• Answer: 140–170  
• Marks: 1  
• Guidance (1 AO1.3a)

Question 10 (b)(iii)  
• Answer: “The (b)(i) prediction is more reliable, as it is within the range of the given data.”  
• Marks: 2  
• Guidance:  
  – (1 AO2.1b, 1 AO2.4a)  
  – B1 for identifying (b)(i) prediction with partial reason (e.g. reference to interpolation vs. extrapolation).

Question 10 (c)  
• Answer: “No, because there may be other factors involved.”  
• Marks: 2  
• Guidance:  
  – (1 AO2.5a, 1 AO3.4b)  
  – B1 for “No” with a partial reason (e.g. weather, different population on certain days).

11.text:
11 (a)  45 000 (2 marks)  
• 2 AO1.3a  
• M1 for 50 000 × 0.9 soi or 50 000 – 5000  

(b)  Total value of goods sold in May was £32 805, which is less than £35 000 (3 marks)  
• 3 AO2.2  
• M2 for 50 000 (or 45 000) × 0.9 used three times (or two times) soi or decreasing by 10% three times  
  OR  
• M1 for 45 000 × 0.9 or 45 000 – 4500  
  – Implied by 36 450 and 32 805  
  – Implied by 40 500  

(c)  8[%] with correct working (5 marks)  
• 3 AO1.3b, 2 AO3.1d  
• B4 for answer 108[%] or 1.08 or [0].08 with correct working  
  OR  
• M3 for 1.2 × [0].9 oe  
  OR for  
  [ 100000×1.2×0.9 – 100000  ] / 100000 × 100  (implied by the given text)  
  OR  
• M2 for 1.2 and [0].9  
  OR  
• M1 for 1.2 or [0].9  

If 0 or 1 scored, instead award SC2 for answer 8[%] with no working or insufficient working.  
If 0 scored, instead award SC1 for 108[%] or 1.08 or [0].08 with no working or insufficient working.  

“Correct working” requires evidence of at least M3 or an alternative convincing approach.  

Throughout, percentage calculations may be performed in stages (e.g. finding 120% by adding 20%).  

For example:  
• 100 000 × 1.2 × [0].9  
  or 120 000 × [0].9  
• 100 000 × 1.2 (implied by 120 000).

15.text:
15 (a)  800 (2 marks)  
   • 1 AO1.3b  
   • 1 AO3.1c  
   M1 for unitary work, e.g. 1 person does 200 letters in 2 hours  

(b)  30 minutes (oe) (4 marks)  
   • 2 AO2.1a  
   • 2 AO3.1d  
   – M1 for 1 person does 100 letters in 1 hour  
   – M1 for 5 people do 1000 letters in 2 hours  
   – M1 for 4 people do 1000 letters in 2.5 hours  
   – Follow through (FT) from their rate in (a) throughout  

(c)  (2 marks)  
   • 1 AO3.4a  
   • 1 AO3.5  
   – Correct comment on the reasonableness of her assumption (e.g. “She has assumed that ‘all day’ means ‘for 24 hours’, but it is not reasonable for them to work without a break.”)  
   – Correct comment on the effect it will have on the answer (e.g. “They can’t work at that rate for that long, so her answer is an over-estimate.”)

18.text:
18 (a)  
• The first error is in step 2.  
• −3x − 2x = −5x, not −x as given.  

Marks and guidance (2 AO2.5a):  
• B1 for identifying step 2.  
• B1 for explaining the error.  

(b)  
[x² + 4x + x + 4 = x² − 3x − 2x + 6]  
x² + 5x + 4 = x² − 5x + 6  
5x + 4 = −5x + 6  
10x + 4 = 6  
10x = 2  
x = 1/5  

Marks and guidance (2 AO1.3a):  
• M1 for an attempt to correct the solution in line with their answer to (a).

19.text:
Correct Answer: (2a + 1) / 4

Mark Allocation:  
• 1 AO1.3b  
• 2 AO3.1b  
• 1 AO3.2  

Marking Guidelines:  
• M1 for summing a + 2 + 3a + 3 + 4a – 1  
• M1 for collecting like terms correctly (e.g. 8a + 4)  
• M1 for dividing the expression 8a + 4 by 4
